## Problem
There is no authentication or authorization validation in the Storage module. All operations are permitted for any caller, creating a critical security vulnerability.

- Write tests for object-level ACL enforcement

- Implement Firebase Auth token validation
- Check bucket-level IAM permissions
- Enforce object-level ACLs (owner, reader, writer)
- Validate signed URLs with proper expiration

### REFACTOR: Add Bucket/Object-Level Policies

- Add support for custom metadata-based access control
- Implement audit logging for access attempts

title: Storage Weak Cryptographic Hash Functions
description:
## Problem
The MD5 hash only processes the first 16 bytes and CRC32C only processes the first 100 bytes of files. This means:
- Hash integrity checks are meaningless for files larger than these limits
- Data corruption beyond these bytes will not be detected
- Upload verification is fundamentally broken

## Location
- src/storage/resumable.ts:458-484

## TDD Approach

### RED: Write Failing Tests
- Write tests with files larger than 16 bytes verifying MD5 hash correctness
- Write tests with files larger than 100 bytes verifying CRC32C correctness
- Write tests comparing hashes with known good values
- Write tests for streaming hash computation on large files (>1GB)
- Write tests for resumable upload hash continuity

### GREEN: Implement Proper Crypto Algorithms
- Use Node.js crypto module for MD5 (crypto.createHash('md5'))
- Use proper CRC32C implementation (consider @node-rs/crc32 or crc32c package)
- Process entire file content through hash functions
- Support streaming hash computation for memory efficiency
- Handle chunked uploads with incremental hashing

### REFACTOR: Use Node.js Crypto Module
- Abstract hash computation into utility functions
- Add hash validation on download as well as upload
- Implement parallel hashing for performance
- Add hash caching for frequently accessed objects
- Consider adding SHA-256 as additional integrity check
close_reason: Fixed MD5 to use Node.js crypto module (processes entire content) and CRC32C to use proper Castagnoli polynomial with full content processing

title: Rules: ReDoS Vulnerability in User Regex
description:
## Problem
The .matches() function accepts user input as regex pattern without validation, creating a ReDoS (Regular Expression Denial of Service) vulnerability.

**Location:** `src/rules/builtins.ts:215`

## TDD Approach

### RED: Write Failing Tests
Write tests with catastrophic backtracking patterns:
- Test with evil regex: (a+)+$
- Test with nested quantifiers: (a*)*b
- Test with overlapping alternation: (a|a)+$
- Test exponential backtracking patterns
- Verify timeout/rejection of malicious patterns
- Test legitimate regex patterns still work
- Test edge cases at complexity boundaries

### GREEN: Make Tests Pass
Add regex validation and timeout:
- Implement regex complexity analysis
- Detect dangerous patterns (nested quantifiers, overlapping groups)
- Add execution timeout for regex matching
- Use safe-regex or similar library for validation
- Reject patterns exceeding complexity threshold
- Consider RE2 or similar safe regex engine

### REFACTOR: Clean Up
Document security considerations:
- Document ReDoS risks in rules documentation
- Add best practices for regex patterns
- Log warnings for potentially slow patterns
- Add configuration for timeout values
- Consider regex pattern allowlist option
